docs.lead_paragraph: The chief medical officer of Cigna discusses the insurer’s ways of improving care and cutting costs.
docs.snippet: The chief medical officer of Cigna discusses the insurer’s ways of improving care and cutting costs.

docs.lead_paragraph: Even as the new health care law expands insurance coverage, another problem faces many areas of the country: a lack of physicians, particularly primary care ones.

headline.seo: Too Few Doctors in Many U.S. Communities
headline.main: Doctor Shortage Likely to Worsen With Health Law
headline.print_headline: Doctor Shortage Likely To Worsen With Health Law

docs.abstract: Health experts say that the shortage of doctors nationwide, particularly primary care physicians, will be exacerbated by the health care reform law because it expands insurance coverage; hold that shortage will lead to slower delivery of care, and say there is little that the government or the medical profession can do to address the shortage by 2014, when the law goes into effect.
docs.snippet: Even as the new health care law expands insurance coverage, another problem faces many areas of the country: a lack of physicians, particularly primary care ones.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

byline.contributor: Annie Lowrey reported from Riverside, and Robert Pear from Washington.
byline.original: By ANNIE LOWREY and ROBERT PEAR

docs.lead_paragraph: A reader responds to “Only the First Step in Containing Health Costs” (Economic View, July 22).
docs.snippet: A reader responds to “Only the First Step in Containing Health Costs” (Economic View, July 22).

docs.lead_paragraph: States that refuse to expand the program will cause needless harm and deaths to thousands of low-income people.

headline.seo: Medicaid After the Supreme Court Decision
headline.main: Medicaid After the Supreme Court Decision
headline.print_headline: Medicaid After the Supreme Court Decision

docs.abstract: Editorial criticizes state officials who want to save money by not expanding Medicaid as required by the health care reform law now that the expansion has been made optional by the Supreme Court; contends that by not expanding the program the officials will be harming their most vulnerable residents.
docs.snippet: States that refuse to expand the program will cause needless harm and deaths to thousands of low-income people.

docs.lead_paragraph: American nuns meeting in St. Louis next week will decide whether to cooperate with three bishops assigned to supervise the overhaul of their organization.

headline.seo: U.S. Nuns Weigh Response to Scathing Vatican Critique
headline.main: Nuns Weigh Response to Scathing Vatican Rebuke
headline.print_headline: Nuns Weigh Response to Scathing Vatican Rebuke

docs.abstract: American nuns meeting in St Louis will try to decide how to respond to a scathing critique of their doctrinal loyalty issued in spring by the Vatican--a report that has prompted Roman Catholics across the country to rally to the nuns' defense; nuns will weigh whether to cooperate with three bishops assigned to supervise the overhaul of their organization, the Leadership Conference of Women Religious.
docs.snippet: American nuns meeting in St. Louis next week will decide whether to cooperate with three bishops assigned to supervise the overhaul of their organization.

docs.lead_paragraph: The 1992 Dream Team sparked the global interest in basketball, but now there is talk of placing limits on participation.

headline.main: N.B.A. Looks to Wake Up From 20-Year Dream
headline.print_headline: N.B.A. Looks to Wake Up From 20-Year Dream

docs.abstract: Inside the Rings; men's basketball's 1992 Dream Team sparked global interest in the sport, but 20 years later, the NBA is reassessing its involvement in the Olympics; basketball officials are toying with the idea of a World Cup, like soccer's.
docs.snippet: The 1992 Dream Team sparked the global interest in basketball, but now there is talk of placing limits on participation.

docs.lead_paragraph: The family of Ms. Seelig, 22, says she suffered an agonizing death because the care she received at a struggling Brooklyn hospital was indifferent to negligent.

headline.seo: The Short Life and Lonely Death of Sabrina Seelig
headline.main: The Short Life and Lonely Death of Sabrina Seelig
headline.print_headline: The Short Life and Lonely Death of Sabrina Seelig

docs.abstract: Case of Sabrina Seelig, who died in 2007 at age 22 at Wyckoff Heights Medical Center in Brooklyn, discussed; Seelig's family, which lost a legal battle against the hospital, continues to believe that she died after indifferent or even negligent care; Seelig had called an ambulance after ingesting a stimulant diet drug and alcohol, which Wyckoff blames for her death; records indicate that she was inappropriately given sedatives and left unmonitored and without further treatment as brain damage set in.
docs.snippet: The family of Ms. Seelig, 22, says she suffered an agonizing death because the care she received at a struggling Brooklyn hospital was indifferent to negligent.

keywords.value: New York City Poison Control Center
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: Nowhere is our health care system more broken and desperate than rural Mississippi. Can an approach used in Iran help save lives?

headline.seo: What Can Mississippi’s Health Care System Learn From Iran?
headline.main: What Can Mississippi Learn From Iran?

docs.abstract: Suzy Hansen article describes the work being done by HealthConnect, an agency in Mississippi whose purpose is to address the dearth of medical services in rural areas of the state; observes that the agency's holistic, intensely personal approach and preventive approach was inspired by the primary health care system created in the 1980s in the Islamic Republic of Iran.
docs.snippet: Nowhere is our health care system more broken and desperate than rural Mississippi. Can an approach used in Iran help save lives?
